objectives: Distinguish when to use ser vs estar
Use ser for identity, origin, and permanent traits
Use estar for location, feelings, and temporary states
Form basic sentences with both verbs

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Profesora
dialogue_blocks.translation: Where are you from, Mr. López?

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sr. López
dialogue_blocks.text: Soy de Veracruz, pero ahora estoy aquí en la capital.
dialogue_blocks.translation: I'm from Veracruz, but now I'm here in the capital.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈsoj ðe βeɾaˈkɾus ˈpeɾo aˈoɾa esˈtoj aˈki en la kapiˈtal]
dialogue_blocks.context: Ser for origin, estar for current location

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sr. López
dialogue_blocks.text: Estoy un poco cansado. Es que trabajo mucho.
dialogue_blocks.translation: I'm a bit tired. It's because I work a lot.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [esˈtoj um ˈpoko kanˈsaðo ‖ es ke tɾaˈβaxo ˈmutʃo]
dialogue_blocks.context: Estar for temporary feeling, ser in fixed expression

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sr. López
dialogue_blocks.text: Sí, soy casado. Mi esposa es médica — es muy inteligente.
dialogue_blocks.translation: Yes, I'm married. My wife is a doctor — she's very intelligent.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈsi ˈsoj kaˈsaðo ‖ mi esˈposa es ˈmeðika ‖ es ˈmuj inteliˈxente]
dialogue_blocks.context: Ser for marital status and profession

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sr. López
dialogue_blocks.text: Está en el hospital. El hospital está en el centro de la ciudad.
dialogue_blocks.translation: She's at the hospital. The hospital is in the city centre.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [esˈta en el ospiˈtal ‖ el ospiˈtal esˈta en el ˈθentɾo ðe la θjuˈðað]
dialogue_blocks.context: Estar for person's location and place's location

srs_flashcards.front: SER: soy, eres, es, somos, son
srs_flashcards.back: I am, you are, he/she is, we are, they are (identity)

srs_flashcards.front: ESTAR: estoy, estás, está, estamos, están
srs_flashcards.back: I am, you are, he/she is... (location/state)
Soy mexicano. Soy médico. Soy de Guadalajara.
srs_flashcards.ipa: [ˈsoj mexiˈkano ‖ ˈsoj ˈmeðiko ‖ ˈsoj ðe ɡwaðalaˈxaɾa]

srs_flashcards.back: Estoy en casa. Estoy cansado. La tienda está cerrada.
srs_flashcards.ipa: [esˈtoj en ˈkasa ‖ esˈtoj kanˈsaðo ‖ la ˈtjenða esˈta θeˈɾaða]

srs_flashcards.back: How are you (now)? vs What are you like (personality)?
The bank is closed. (temporary state → estar)
He is a doctor (profession) / He is sick (state)

feedback.correct: ¡Correcto! Origin uses SER: 'Mi abuela es de Oaxaca.'
feedback.incorrect: For origin, always use SER: '¿De dónde eres?' — 'Soy de...'.

exercises.instruction: Une la frase con el uso correcto de ser/estar

pairs.spanish: La biblioteca está en el centro.

exercises.instruction: Completa con ser o estar (forma correcta)

speaking_rubric.title: Preséntate completamente
speaking_rubric.scenario: Introduce yourself fully: name, origin, profession, and how you're feeling today.
speaking_rubric.prompt: Usa ser y estar para presentarte y decir cómo estás.

scoring_criteria.description: Ser and estar forms clearly distinguished
Both verbs used correctly at least once each

sample_response.text: Me llamo Claudia. Soy de México. Soy estudiante. Hoy estoy un poco cansada pero estoy bien.
sample_response.ipa: [me ˈʝamo ˈklawðja ‖ ˈsoj ðe ˈmexiko ‖ ˈsoj estu ˈðjante ‖ ˈoj esˈtoj um ˈpoko kanˈsaða ˈpeɾo esˈtoj ˈβjen]

cultural_notes.formality: Ser/estar is the most common challenge for English speakers learning Spanish. In Mexico, 'estar casado' (estar for married) and 'ser casado' are both used — estar is slightly more common. Context resolves ambiguity.
cultural_notes.gestures: No specific gesture for this grammar point, but teachers often use two hands to represent the two verbs — permanent (closed fist = SER) vs temporary (open palm = ESTAR).
cultural_notes.regional_variations: '¿Cómo estamos?' (How are we doing?) is a warm, inclusive greeting in Mexico used by shopkeepers, teachers, and hosts. It uses estar but feels like a fixed expression.

acceptance_criteria: Location, feelings, origin, profession all covered
